# Bipolar Junction Transistor ( BJT)

<span style="color:#336600">Biasing of a transistor:</span>

![](l4.3-dc-biasing-bipolar-junction-transistor-img/l43-dc-biasing-bipolar-junction-transistor_1.png)

<span style="color:#0000ff">Linear operation: larger output has same shape as input except that it is inverted</span>

If an amplifier is not biased with correct dc voltages on the input and output\, it can go into  <span style="color:#ff0000">saturation or </span>  <span style="color:#ff0000">cutoff</span>  <span style="color:#ff0000"> when an input signal is applied\.</span>

![](l4.3-dc-biasing-bipolar-junction-transistor-img/l43-dc-biasing-bipolar-junction-transistor_2.png)

<span style="color:#0000ff">Nonlinear operation: output voltage limited \(clipped\) by </span>  <span style="color:#0000ff">cutoff</span>

![](l4.3-dc-biasing-bipolar-junction-transistor-img/l43-dc-biasing-bipolar-junction-transistor_3.png)

<span style="color:#0000ff">Nonlinear operation: output voltage limited \(clipped\) by saturation</span>

<span style="color:#0000cc">The region along the load line including all points between saturation and </span>  <span style="color:#0000cc">cutoff</span>  <span style="color:#0000cc"> is known as the linear region of the transistor’s operation</span> \.

Note: If the transistor is operated in this region\, the output voltage is  <span style="color:#ff0000"> __ideally__ </span>  a linear reproduction of the input\.
